source: Private discussion-style data from forums (e.g., Reddit, Discord, Quora, LinkedIn)

level_1: I asked on Reddit if LinkedIn matters for students. Everyone said — YES!
In my college Discord, seniors told us to keep our LinkedIn updated even if we’re in 2nd year.
I posted a basic project on GitHub and someone starred it — felt amazing!
One person said: 'Think of GitHub as your coding diary — write regularly.'
A classmate got an internship because his GitHub had a clean README.
level_2: In a Quora thread, someone said a good profile photo makes your LinkedIn 5x more clickable.
A mentor told me: 'You’re more visible when your profile looks alive.'
In our GDSC group, we reviewed each other’s LinkedIn — helped a lot!
One of us added LinkedIn links in their resume and got callbacks faster.
GitHub profiles with stars and clean repos get shared more in dev groups.
level_3: On a Reddit AMA, a recruiter said: 'We check LinkedIn before the CV.'
In a Telegram group, people discussed how weekly posts improve visibility.
One friend posts a project update every Sunday — now has 2k+ LinkedIn followers.
Open-source mentors said: 'A well-structured GitHub is better than 10 certificates.'
GitHub readmes are like your pitch deck — show your thought process.
level_4: A DevRel professional on Twitter said: 'Your personal brand is how people remember you.'
LinkedIn creators often suggest building in public — share progress, not just results.
One senior shared his resume, GitHub, and LinkedIn — all branded with one color and tone.
A top answer on Quora said: 'Be consistent, not perfect. That’s the secret to branding.'
A recruiter told me: 'I noticed you because of your weekly learning posts.'
